name: calculus

calculus noun
(CALCULATION)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ U ]
  mathematics
  specialized an area of advanced mathematics in which continuously changing values are studied: Did you do calculus at A level? It is essential to understand functions and derivatives, key building blocks in calculus.
[ singular ] a way of calculating, judging, or deciding something in a complicated situation: There is a very tricky political calculus involved here. The piece about jury screening discusses the decision-making calculus itself. The new legislation changes the calculus for car manufacturers.
More examplesFewer examplesMany people are terrified of learning calculus.If turnout were to increase by just a few percent, that would change the calculus of our elections.

calculus noun
(MEDICAL)
[ C ]
  medical
  specialized plural calculi a mass of a hard mineral substance that is formed in the body, for example in the kidneys or gall bladder: Stones that form in the kidney or bladder are called urinary calculi. See also
gallstone
kidney stone
[ U ]
  medical
  specialized a hard substance that forms on the teeth: The disease process begins when plaque on the tooth hardens to tartar, which hardens further to become calcified tartar, or calculus. Compare
tartar
More examplesFewer examplesMeasures to remove biliary tract calculi can be considered, although from the present study stones recurred in 12 of 12 patients.A 70-year-old male with gout and known renal calculi presents with left flank pain.Because your body is fighting off the calculus, periodontal disease is stressing the entire immune system.The body attacks the calculus below the gum line, leading to inflammation and bleeding gums.
